However, the V/Q ratio is not maximum at the base; it is actually lower at the base due to higher perfusion relative to ventilation. Ventilation per unit lung volume is greater at the base due to gravity, which increases ventilation efficiency there, contradicting the claim that it is maximum at the apex. Blood circulation is greater at the base due to gravity, making the statement that blood circulation is minimum at the base incorrect. analysis: In pulmonary ventilation, the distribution of ventilation and perfusion across the lung is influenced by gravity. The apex of the lung has a higher ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) ratio due to relatively less perfusion compared to ventilation, leading to a higher partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) at the apex. The base of the lung, on the other hand, has greater blood flow due to gravity, resulting in a lower V/Q ratio. Ventilation per unit lung volume is actually greater at the base, not the apex, due to the effects of gravity on lung mechanics. Blood circulation is also greater at the base, not minimum. Therefore, the true statement is that PaO2 is maximum at the apex.
